awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Collaborative Research: Environmental Fate and Effects of Dichloroacetamide Safeners: An Overlooked Class of Emerging Contaminants?
awd_abstract_narration:
PI Names:  John Sivey
Proposal Number:  1703796 

Many of the herbicide formulations applied to crop fields include a safener. Safeners are so-called "inert" ingredients, which are added to protect crops (but not weeds) from possible damage caused by herbicides. Safeners have application rates on par with many herbicide active ingredients; however, unlike most herbicide active ingredients, the environmental fate and effects of safeners are poorly understood. The purpose of this project is to address the extensive knowledge gaps associated with the environmental fate and ecological effects of a major class of safeners. This collaborative project unites a multidisciplinary team of experts and students from a primarily undergraduate institution (Towson University) and a doctoral-granting institution (University of Iowa) with the goal of promoting sustainable agricultural practices related to the use of safeners. 

This project seeks to advance our understanding of the environmental persistence and ecotoxicological risks of dichloroacetamide safeners and their transformation products. Despite being classified as "inert", safeners are biologically active and their bioactivity is anticipated to increase via selected environmental transformations (including photolysis and reductive dechlorination). Due to their extensive use, safeners likely represent an overlooked class of emerging contaminants. Using commercial safeners and their herbicidal co-formulants, this project will (1) determine their rates and mechanisms of photochemical transformation in surface waters; (2) quantify their extent of removal and/or transformation during simulated drinking water treatment; (3) establish timescales associated with their biotransformation; (4) identify products of these transformations, including how reactions alter enantiomeric signatures of chiral safeners; and (5) evaluate ecotoxicological risks of safeners and their transformation products toward non-target aquatic organisms. Commercial formulations can include enantiomerically-enriched herbicides co-formulated with racemic mixtures of safeners. As such, experiments will include individual safener enantiomers, safener racemates, and safener + herbicide binary mixtures representative of commercial formulations. As safener use is projected to increase in the future, there is urgent need to obtain reliable environmental assessment data for this chemical class. This project will provide some of the first non-industrial data necessary to assess persistence and risk associated with safeners in natural and engineered aquatic systems. Moreover, as dichloroacetamide safeners are applied extensively to corn used for food, animal feed, and biofuel production, this work confronts challenges to sustainable development at the food-energy-water nexus. As society grows increasingly reliant on agrochemical advances to feed a swelling population, this work promotes sustainable agriculture by guiding the design of environmentally-benign safener formulations. Central to this project is a research partnership between a PUI (Towson University) and an R1 (University of Iowa).  A signature effort of this partnership is the participation of undergraduates in the Summer Research Opportunities Program (SROP) at the University of Iowa. SROP provides promising underrepresented students with research experience, in addition to workshops and seminars designed to enhance academic success and promote graduate education in STEM.  In total, two graduate and several undergraduate students will receive training at the interface of environmental engineering, analytical chemistry, and toxicology, which will help to better prepare tomorrow's research leaders and technical workforce to confront the multi-faceted challenges at the food-energy-water nexus.

por.por_cntn:
Herbicide formulations are among the most abundantly applied agrochemicals worldwide. Herbicide active ingredients are used to control weeds, but herbicides can also damage the crops they are intended to protect. Therefore, another class of chemicals called safeners are commonly added to herbicide formulations. Safener reduce damage to crops caused by herbicides. The key goals of this research were focused on an improved understanding of the environmental fate and effects of one class of safeners called dichloroacetamides. Dichloroacetamide safeners are commonly applied to corn, wheat, and rice, among other crops. These safeners are anticipated to be mobile in the environment, with a high probability of runoff into streams and percolation into groundwater.

Intellectual Merits

Our environmental fate studies evaluated the reactivity of dichloroacetamide safeners in reactions with water, acid, and base. Our findings indicate that dichloroacetamide safeners typically react more rapidly with water, acid, and base compared to the herbicide active ingredients with which dichloroacetamides are commonly co-formulated. Upon reacting with water, we discovered that safeners can transform into products of potential toxicological concern, including a compound (dichloroacetate) that is currently a regulated contaminant in drinking water.

We also examined what happens to safeners in chlorinated water. Such studies permit us to predict how safeners will behave in most municipal drinking waters. We discovered that some safeners (furilazole and dichlormid) react quickly with chlorine; other safeners (benoxacor and AD-67) react more slowly with chlorine. Safeners were less reactive toward chloramine compared to chlorine.

When natural waters are chlorinated, the bromide that is naturally present in the water can be converted into bromine. We determined that the resulting bromine reacts with safeners more quickly than does chlorine. Upon reacting with bromine or chlorine, safeners can generate products (e.g., epoxides and bromine-substituted compounds) that are anticipated to be more toxic than the safeners themselves.

We also discovered that safeners are not toxic to algae. Moreover, safeners do not appear to protect algae from harm caused by herbicides. In fact, herbicide active ingredients were similarly toxic to algae compared to their respective formulations containing herbicides, safeners, and other inert ingredients.

When we considered a broader range of toxicological endpoints in single- and multi-species systems, we discovered that the safener benoxacor seemed to inhibit feeding in the freshwater invertebrate, Daphnia magna. Specifically, Daphnia magna exposed to benoxacor and fed algae were the same size as control daphnia that were not fed algae. This was an important and unexpected result as there is no evidence in the literature of this type of behavioral effect of a safener on a freshwater animal. These types of sublethal effects have important implications for community dynamics and warrant additional research.

In the same multi-species studies, we also found that the apparent biotransformation (i.e., reactions driven by organisms) of the herbicide S-metolachlor increased with increasing number of species. This result, too, is novel and points to the potential role that biodiversity can play in the fate and effects of agrochemicals.

Our results have uncovered several interesting dynamics that have improved our understanding of the fate and effects of safeners but also suggest that more research is warranted. Specifically, it is important to more fully define the circumstances under which safeners may cause adverse behavioral effects to aquatic animals. Additionally, our results related to herbicide biotransformation provide further evidence of the services provided by more biodiverse ecosystems. A more thorough understanding of how biodiversity influences chemical fate and transport may lead to important insights and additional motivation to conserve biodiversity.

Broader Impacts

Student training in a multidisciplinary environment.  Two graduate and 13 undergraduate students were trained on this interdisciplinary project at the interface of environmental engineering, analytical chemistry, and ecotoxicology. Our collaborative research environment enhanced the professional training of tomorrow’s STEM leaders.

Training of future faculty members.  This project supported the development and delivery of a three-day, online symposium entitled Preparing for Faculty Positions at Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUIs). Delivered in January 2021 and directed by Dr. John Sivey, this symposium informed future faculty members about what academic life entails at PUIs. The symposium was divided into three discussion panels; recordings of each panel are freely available online:

•    Session #1 – Preparing for Teaching Success at a PUI – https://youtu.be/-TUeHnULmhM  

•    Session #2 – Preparing for Research Success at a PUI – https://youtu.be/17_NMgI7rMU   

•    Session #3 –Preparing Successful Applications for Faculty Positions at PUIs – https://youtu.be/zRQiNUgm63c  

Promoting societally relevant outcomes.  Despite the important role of safeners in increasing yields of important crops, the peer-reviewed literature is largely silent on the question, “Are safeners safe?” We contend that the increased understanding of the environmental behavior of safeners obtained from this work will improve future agrochemical formulations while promoting environmental sustainability.
